JSmcPrIi.question: Which answer lists only sub-categories of undesired aircraft states according to the TEM concept?

options.text: Ground navigation, aircraft configuration
Organisation, environment
Aircraft situation, communication
Aircraft handling, procedural

MPi1XtHj.question: A pilot using a checklist is an example of the interaction within the SHELL concept of...

options.text: L and S.
L and H.
L and L.
L and E.

VGyrK76V.question: With reference to the SHELL concept: the pilot misinterpretation of the old three-point altimeter would be an example of an interface mismatch between the following components:

Liveware - Environment.
Liveware - Software.
Liveware - Liveware.

spKpFJpK.question: According to the Threat and Error Management (TEM) model, What is the correct definition of "undesired aircraft state"?

options.text: It is an undesired flight situation associated with a reduction in margins of safety.
Accidents that are the result of undesired actions or inactions by the flight crew.
It is an event or error that occurs beyond the influence of the flight crew, increases operational complexity and must be managed to maintain an acceptable margin of safety.
Actions or inactions by the flight crew that lead to deviations from organisational or flight crew intentions or expectations.

KZeUbpIR.question: With reference to the SHELL Model, S represents...

options.text: Software (which includes checklists).
Symbology (which includes safety).
Self-awareness (which includes safety).
Security (which includes safety).
3 and 4
1, 4 and 5

osRHNLqw.question:
A pilot becomes skilled when he/she:

1. trains or practises regularly2. knows how to manage himself/herself3. possesses all the knowledge associated with the aircraft4. knows how to keep resources in reserve for coping with the unexpected.

options.text: 1 and 2 only
considered to be a sub-set of national culture.
considered to be independent of national culture.
NOT a product of national culture.
NOT a sub-set of national culture.

1ZvQQJU6.question: Which statement concerning organisational threats is true (TEM model)?

options.text: Organisational threats can be controlled (for example removed or, at least, minimised) at source by aviation organisations and are usually latent in nature.
Organisational threats are rarely latent in nature.
Organisational threats can normally be planned for during flight planning but some will arise spontaneously, but they all have to be managed by flight crews in real time.
Organisational threats occur due to the environment in which flight operations take place.

xOroTqYM.question: Civil aviation is generally recognised for being

options.text: an open culture activity.
an open culture but restricted to maintenance personnel.
a closed culture activity.
an open culture but restricted to cabin crew.

sQls8lkP.question: Which of the following is considered an organisational threat, according to the TEM model?

options.text: Using incorrect or expired charts
Flight over mountainous terrain, valleys and built-up areas.
En-route weather such as wind, ice, or turbulence
Implementation of a new safety management system (SMS)

XVsD2kcP.question: The role of a “learning culture” within a good safety culture is that:

options.text: Processes and procedures must be adjusted to detect threats and errors.

Dangerous violations must have appropriate consequences for the violator.
Safety relevant information is given to all employees concerned.

z5lBri1y.question: With regard to the Swiss Cheese model, what is true about the holes?

options.text: They represent errors in the system, which can lead to an accident.
The passage through such a hole means that an accident has become inevitable.
They can be closed by strict adherence to SOPs.
They are the solutions that have to be found in critical situations in order to avoid an accident.

jlYJ9Uqi.question:

2) ACAS.

4) call-outs.
5) personal strategies and tactics.
6) TAWS.

wrO1zC57.question: Refer to the TEM model and give an example for an organisational threat:

options.text: de-icing error of the ground crew
taxiway contamination
turbulence
traffic congestion

sINy2ky3.question: Which of the following factors contributes to a safety culture?

options.text: The highest levels of management making the necessary resources available.
Developing trust through rewarding good employees and punishing those who make mistakes.
Safety being primarily an issue imposed on the employees by various administrative systems.
Encouraging employees to report errors while taking minimum corrective action.

WyLs7Wvf.question: Which of the following factors contributes to a safety culture?

options.text: The highest levels of management making the necessary resources available.
Safety being primarily an issue imposed on the employees by various administrative systems.
Developing trust through rewarding good employees and punishing those who make mistakes.
Encouraging employees to report erors while taking minimum corrective action.

Mcko3pmD.question: According to Annex 1 of the Convention on International Civil Aviation, competency is defined as

options.text: a combination of skills, knowledge and attitudes required to perform a task to the prescribed standard.
a set of behaviours that provide a structured guide for the identification, evaluation and development of the behaviours in individuals.
a mental state or quality of being adequately or well qualified, having the ability to perform a specific role.
a collection of practical and theoretical knowledge, cognitive skills, behaviour and values used to improve performance.

vXqWPDWx.question: Consider the training and assessment of pilots. Which of the following is one of the eight core competencies?

options.text: Situation awareness
Captaincy
Judgement and determination
Synergy

wGdHsBYc.question: Consider the training and assessment of pilots. Which of the following is one of the eight core competencies?

options.text: Judgement and determination
Synergy
Situational awareness
Captaincy

i0GzjXAA.question: Consider the Threat and Error Management (TEM) model. Which of the following situations is considered an undesired aircraft state?

options.text: A higher approach speed than cleared by ATC.
An approach attempt to an aerodrome with predicted wind shear.
The inadvertent selection of a lower flap setting than recommended by the performance planning tool.
A hard landing resulting in the collapse of the landing gear.

zxSR7TY3.question: According to the TEM model, what are the effective counter-measures used to detect and manage foreseeable threats?

options.text: Briefings and situational awareness.
Aeronautical decision making management and briefings.
Discussing procedures and aeronautical decision making management.
Situational awareness and discussing procedures.

oIig9c3u.question: How is the SHELL model relevant to the work in the cockpit?

options.text: It helps to identify possible sources of error, and to remove possible causes of error in the performance of flying tasks.
The Hardware-Liveware interface addresses the ability of the crew to adapt to the physical environment, such as seating, placing of the aircraft controls, air quality.
The Software-Liveware interface refers to cockpit automation, which can be a source of error where flight crew have insufficient knowledge of computer systems.
The Liveware-Environment interface refers to the aircraft environment, and the crew use standard operating procedures to function there.

HKjkDfR6.question: Consider the Threat and Error Management (TEM) model. A flight crew experiences an undesired aircraft state (UAS). The most correct course of action is to:

options.text: Take immediate countermeasures to recover to a normal operational state.
Contact the Operator and request to practice this specific situation in the next training session.
Continue with the current configuration and file a safety report upon landing.
Continue with the current configuration as an UAS is not an outcome and therefore the safety of the flight remains unaffected.

d34aszQI.question: A typical example of an undesired aircraft state according to the TEM model would be:

options.text: Flying too fast and/or too high during an approach.
Missing readback clearances between flight crew and ATC.
Approaching a runway with a crosswind component.
Using an incorrect communication frequency.

nnWq7zFg.question: Which of the following is a typical example of an procedural error according to the TEM model?

options.text: Applying a rule not appropriate to the situation
Missing readback of clearances between flight crew and ATC
Taxiing on the wrong taxiway
Flying below the correct glideslope

9quGr6NA.question: The pilot monitoring speaks out loud whenever he/she changes an input setting on a navigation instrument. The pilot flying detects an error in one digit set and immediately point out the mistake so that it can be corrected. This is an example of threat and error management (TEM)...

options.text: execution-countermeasure, aimed to help detect possible errors.
review-countermeasure, which is required to cross-check actions of the other crew member.
planning-countermeasure, useful to help prevent latent threats.
prevention-countermeasure, designed to avoid errors in instrument settings.

M0F82vSy.question: Concerning the TEM model, when is an error classified as procedural error?

options.text: In order to be classified as procedural error, the pilot or flight crew must be interacting with a procedure.
In order to be classified as procedural error, the pilot or flight crew must be interacting with the aircraft.
In order to be classified as procedural error, the pilot or flight crew must be interacting with a people.
In order to be classified as procedural error, the pilot or flight crew must be interacting with a procedure, with people or with the aircraft.

Uy0wBLQK.question: Select the option which is not a Procedural Error (TEM model):

options.text: Ground navigation: attempting to turn down wrong taxiway or runway, taxi too fast, failure to hold short or missed taxiway or runway.

Documentation: wrong weight and balance, fuel information, ATIS, or clearance information recorded, misinterpreted items on paperwork; incorrect logbook entries or incorrect application of MEL procedures.
Callouts: omitted/incorrect callouts.
Checklists: wrong challenge and response; items missed, checklist performed late or at the wrong time.

TquZEzEA.question: Which of the following statements concerning culture is correct?

options.text: An informed culture actively collects, analyses and distributes safety-related data.
In a learning culture, committed errors can be voiced without risking negative consequences for oneself.
A just culture is a culture in which errors made in flight are never prosecuted in order to encourage pilots to openly communicate them.
In an open culture, the highest good is the well-being of the society as a whole.

IJRM6C5d.question: Cultivating an atmosphere where people have confidence to report safety concerns without fear of blame is an example of a/an:

options.text: Reporting Culture.
Safety Culture.
Open Culture.
Learning Culture.

ieGKxLDF.question: Threats, with regard to the TEM model, are grouped in two basic categories. One of these categories refers to organisational threats and the other category refers to:

options.text: environmental threats that occur due to the environment in which flight operations take place.
human performance threats that occur due to the human performance of aviation personnel.
operational threats which are caused by the actual operation of the aircraft itself.
technical threats that occur due to the technical part of the aeronautical operations, e.g. aircraft malfunctions.

WmdYFsc5.question: Threats, with regard to the TEM model, are grouped in two basic categories. One of these categories refers to environmental threats and the other category refers to:

options.text: organisational threats that occur due to the organisation in aviation structures.
technical threats that occur due to the technical part of the aeronautical operations, e.g. aircraft malfunctions.
human performance threats that occur due to the human performance of aviation personnel.
operational threats which are caused by the actual operation of the aircraft itself.

b7vYa7kT.question: In a company, a safety culture is established where a person is not legally prosecuted when committing an error without intent, but where intentional violation or negligent behavior are not tolerated. This safety culture is called...

fhTI6KRe.question: In a company, a safety culture is established where a person is not legally prosecuted when committing an error without consent, but where intentional violation or negligent behavior are not tolerated. This safety culture is called?

options.text: Just culture

tg6ILYMF.question: Considering a typical civil aviation environment, what can be said about the following statement? “The Safety Culture is relatively enduring, stable and resistant to change.”

options.text: It is true.

Neither true nor false. Characteristics of Safety Cultures vary significantly among the organizations and depend on many factors. In many organizations the Safety Culture can be stable and resistant to change while in many other ones it might be relatively unstable and not resistant to change.
It is false.

Neither true nor false. Safety Culture has nothing to do with aviation as it is always defined primarily by the generally prevailing attitude characteristics within a specific geographic region or a country.

recognizes three types of human errors, namely anticipated, unanticipated and latent errors.

jCzIGswW.question: The three basic components of the Threat and Error Management (TEM) model are, from the perspective of flight crews, threats, errors and undesired aircraft states. With regards to errors, the TEM model...

options.text: considers three categories of errors, namely aircraft handling, procedural and communications.
differentiates between three kinds of errors, namely aircraft handling, navigation and aircraft configuration.
distinguishes three classes of errors, namely operational, organisational and environmental.
recognises three types of human errors, namely anticipated, unanticipated and latent errors.

h1pszA70.question: The three basic components of the Threat and Error Management (TEM) model are, from the perspective of flight crews, threats, errors and undesired aircraft states. With regard to errors, the TEM model..

options.text: considers three categories of errors, namely aircraft handling, procedural and communications.
differentiates between three kinds of errors, namely aircraft handling, navigation and aircraft configuration.
distinguishes three classes of errors, namely operational, organisational and environmental.
recognizes three types of human errors, namely anticipated, unanticipated and latent errors.

I0UfOZCa.question: According to the TEM Mode, threats are grouped in two basic categories. One of these categories refers to environmental threats and the other category refers to:

options.text: Organisational threats that occur due to the organisation in aviation structures.
Human performance threats that occur due to the human performance of aviation personnel.
Operational threats that occur due to the organisation in aviation structures.
Technical threats that occur due to the technical part of the aeronautical operations, e.g. aircraft malfunctions.

uRBU17Qg.question: An example of an environmental threat in the TEM model is:

options.text: A volcanic eruption on your flight route.
Your operator being close to administration.
Being stressed due to pre-flight delays.
Missing a line in the checklist.

ygbjGHil.question: Refer to the TEM model and give an example of a latent threat:

options.text: shortened turn-around schedules
thunderstorm
mountains
congested airport

CEnDRSdt.question: With reference to the TEM model, a latent threat is:

options.text: a threat which is not directly obvious or observably by the flight crew.
an anticipated threat, since it can be expected or known to the flight crew.
always an environmental threat.
is an unexpected threat and flight crews must apply skills and knowledge acquired through training and operational experience.

0PYNx5S6.question: Consider TEM. Which of the following is an example of an organisational threat?

options.text: Using incorrect or expired charts.
Implementing a safety management system.
Flying over mountains, valleys, and built-up areas.
Weather en-route including turbulence, ice and wind.

efmj8MBO.question: According to the TEM model, which of the following is an environmental threat?

options.text: Expired approach Chart
Exceeded holdover time after de-icing
Smoking before the flight
Contaminated runway

tw2HUvwF.question: Which of the following is the most important basis for a good safety culture?

options.text: A non-punitive reporting system
A 'critical incident stress management' system
An accident research group
A management willing to accept 'lessons learnt'

U5vw0uj9.question: Which statement is true regarding an undesired aircraft state (TEM model)?

options.text: Undesired aircraft states are flight crew-induced aircraft position or speed deviations, associated with a reduction in margins of safety.
ATC controller errors can reduce margins of safety in flight operations and would be considered as undesired aircraft threats.
Events such as equipment malfunctions are considered to be undesired aircraft states when associated with a reduction in margins of safety,.
Events such as equipment malfunctions are considered to be undesired aircraft states.

QuWwiT9z.question: Which statement is true regarding an undesired aircraft state (TEM model)?

options.text: Undesired aircraft states are flight crew-induced aircraft position or speed deviations, associated with a reduction in margins of safety.
ATC controller errors can reduce margins of safety in flight operations and would be considered as undesired aircraft states.
Events such as equipment malfunctions are considered to be undesired aircraft states when associated with a reduction in margins of safety,.
Events such as equipment malfunctions are considered to be undesired aircraft states.

IuartuyD.question: Using the sleep credit/debit model, 8 hours sleep produces a sleep credit of..

options.text: 16 hours.
4 hours.
8 hours.
18 hours.

yJGM9D3S.question: Which of the following options lists the elements of the SHELL concept?

options.text: Software, hardware, environment, and liveware.
Software, harmony, environment, and location.
Software, hardware, environment, and location.
Concept. Software, hardware, economy, and liveware.

JExkJwJO.question: How many bouts of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep typically occur in an 8-hour sleep period?

options.text: 4 or 5
6 or 7
2 or 3
8 or 9

vsEKzn8V.question: Which is true regarding the interaction between various elements of the SHELL model?

options.text: The liveware is the hub of the SHELL model; therefore the non-human components should be adapted and matched to this central component.
Temperature, pressure, humidity, noise and time of day can all be reflected in performance and also in well being.
Information processing can be stimulated by mind sets and vigilance.
Proficiency testing should be done on an individual basis to avoid SHELL element mismatch.

b9QpfrT5.question: In order to completely resynchronise with local time after zone crossing, circadian rhythms require..

options.text: less time when flying from east to west.
more time when flying from east to west.
about one day per 2.5 hours of time shift.
about one week per 2.5 hours of time shift.

P75rY4dx.question: Boyle's law is directly applicable in case of:

options.text: the expansion of trapped gases in the human body with increasing altitude.
the occurrence of decompression sickness at high altitude.
hyperventilation with increasing altitude.
the occurrence of hypoxia with increasing altitude.

i1sj8Pdq.question: What is the main purpose of a checklist?

options.text: To enable the crew to carry out a procedure in a well-defined and orderly manner.
To conform with the requirements of the Flight Manual.
To enable any pilot to fly a particular aircraft.
To ensure that all possible contingencies are covered by procedures.

tVIXcsPL.question: Which of the following can be classified as a latent threat to flight crew?

options.text: An equipment design issue.
An in-flight aircraft malfunction.
Flying into a known, congested airport.
A predicted thunderstorm.

aiUjNFWh.question:
Consider a scenario where you are on a flight deck for long flight which is highly automated. You expect smooth and uneventful flight and completed all the checks for the next 30 mins. You started to become tired slowly.
Which are you most at risk of suffering at this point?

options.text: Hypovigilance
Sleepwalking
Paradoxical sleep
Hypervigilance

mXkBsz9y.question: Consider a scenario where you are on a flight deck for long flight which is highly automated. You expect smooth and uneventful flight and completed all the checks for the next 30 mins. You started to become tired slowly. Which are you most at risk of suffering at this point?

options.text: Hypovigilance
Hypervigilance
Sleepwalking
Paradoxical sleep

zoT4GgUE.question: Confrontation in high power distance cultures is

options.text: generally avoided.
always avoided.
always promoted.
generally promoted.

arYlLegf.question: What does the H in the SHELL model mean?

options.text: Hardware
Human
Happy
Health

O9JaZt0z.question: Fill in the blank Safety culture is ___ of national culture.

options.text: a subpart
not a subpart
not related
independent

R0uqpHWM.question: In a cockpit environment, what skin cream should you use?

options.text: Aqua based.
Occlusive moisturizers.
Mixed-skin cream.
Oil based.

yauzAo2T.question: When a pilot is controlling an aircraft, the ability to maintain level flight while adjusting the power, without effort or continuous thought, is a skill kept in the...

options.text: Long term memory.
Short term memory.
Semantic memory.
Working memory.
is characterised by withdrawn crew members and unclear communication.
always results from an over-relaxed atmosphere.
is characterised by a highly efficient crew, communicating appropriately with the outside.
is not very dangerous as each person checks everything personally.

OhWpOcNE.question: The development of procedures makes pilots more effective and more reliable in their actions. This is called:

options.text: procedural consistency.
knowledge based behaviour.
procedural confusion.
mental model.

E4Ywi6QX.question: Which of the following statements best characterise a self-centred cockpit?

options.text: Without taking note of what the other crew members are doing, each one does their own thing while at the same time assuming that everyone is aware of what is being done or what is going on.
The communication between crew members always increases when the captain takes charge of a situation.
While decreasing communication, the independence of each crew member bolsters the crew’s synergy.
The egoistic and self-centred personality of the captain often leads to a synergetic cockpit whereby decisions are taken by the captain but prepared by the crew.

XOYKB4OG.question: Which of the following statements best characterizes a self-centred cockpit?

options.text: Without taking note of what the other members are doing, each one does his own thing while at the same time assuming that everyone is aware of what is being done or what is going on.
While decreasing communication, the independence of each member bolsters the crew's synergy.
The communication between crew members always increases when the captain takes charge of a situation.
The egocentric personality of the captain often leads to a synergetic cockpit.

2M99E9nU.question:
An air traffic controller clears the crew of a Boeing 737 aircraft to descend to FL330, thereafter, he instructs the crew of an Airbus A320 to climb to FL320. The Boeing crew correctly reads back and complies with the issued clearance. The Airbus crew incorrectly reads back their climb clearance to FL330 instead of FL320, and the co-pilot programs the FMS for a climb to FL330. After the incorrect readback, the aircraft is handed over to another controller who notes the selected FL but doesn’t realise it is wrong.
With regard to communication, state which kind of error occurred...

options.text: Explicit, which is subject to confirmation bias.
Implicit, which is subject to misunderstandings due to omissions.
Explicit, which is subject to misunderstandings due to omissions.
Implicit, which is subject to confirmation bias.

aSZIDJzP.question: A pilot can be described as being proficient, when he/she

options.text: has automated a large part of the necessary flight deck routine operations in order to free his/her cognitive resources.
knows how to off-load all his/her resources to the automation of tasks.
is capable of maintaining a high level of arousal during the greater portion of the flight.
is able to reduce his/her arousal to a low level during the entire flight.

88EvpvBf.question: The choice of words and their packaging become more important in the cockpit of an aircraft because:

options.text: Loss of body language
Loss of perception
Loss of hypertext
Loss of situational awareness

08VOLbZX.question: The percentage of aeroplane accidents caused by human error is approximately

0QuHam50.question:
Analyse the following communication exchange between a pilot and an air traffic controller (ATC): 
  
 (1) ATC: EZY8496, climb level 320 
 (2) Pilot: Climbing level 300, EZY8496 
  
 The pilot then inserts level "300" in the FMS. What type of error is being described? Why didn't the controller notice that the readback was not correct?

options.text: Explicit; and the ATC expected the readback to be correct and did not focus on it.
Implicit; and the ATC could interpret the pilot's readback in different ways.
Implicit; due to faulty communication equipment, he could not hear the pilot.
Explicit; and ATC did not understand the message.

zK12PWMu.question: Safety is often improved by applying the principles of CRM, e.g.:

options.text: expression of doubts or of a different opinion.
abstention from any suggestion which might be untimely.
the avoidance of any conflict in order to preserve the crew’s synergy.
unquestioned obedience to all the Captain’s decisions.

JPz5BhLn.question: Safety is often improved by applying the principles of CRM, e.g.:

options.text: expression of doubts or of a different opinion.
the avoidance of any conflict in order to preserve the crews synergy.
unquestioned obedience to all the captain's decisions.
abstention from any suggestion which might be untimely.
severely hampers the decision making process.
guarantees the appropriate decision making in critical situations.
is absolutely necessary for a safe flight operation.
is the most important attribute of a line pilot.

vVjSywyk.question:
Why must flight safety considerations consider the human error mechanism?
1) It is analysis of an incident or accident which will make it possible to identify what error has been committed and by whom. It is the process whereby the perpetrator is made responsible which may lead to elimination of the error.
2) If we have a better understanding of the cognitive error mechanism, it will be possible to adapt procedures, aircraft interfaces, etc.
3) It is error management procedure which enables us to continuously adjust our actions. The better we understand the underlying mechanism of an error, the better will be our means for detecting and adapting future errors.
4) Since error is essentially human, once it has been identified by the use of procedures, a person will be able to anticipate and deal with it automatically in the future.
The correct statement(s) is (are):

SfdAxQuB.question: Which of the following statements is an example of a countermeasure that may be used by flight crew in order to manage threats, errors, and undesired aircraft states?

options.text: Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).
Mismanagement of aircraft systems.
Maintaining the aircraft's anti-icing settings OFF during icing conditions.
Complacency.

7BGcK8as.question: Competency, according ICAO Annex 1, is based on

options.text: combination of skills, knowledge and attitudes required to perform a task to the prescribed standard.
combination of skills and knowledge required to perform a task to the prescribed standard.
combination of skills, knowledge and resources to perform a task to the prescribed standard.
combination of skills and resource required to perform a task to the prescribed standard.
